content:
With all the serious issues facing the country, and the world, strange that a Tweet at 12:06 a.m. from the personal Twitter account of @President Donald J. Trump would be the "talker" of the day. 
Or maybe not so strange.
People are having a lot of fun using "covfefe" as the latest word craze. 
But today at The White House press briefing - which was an AUDIO ONLY experience, no live TV cameras allowed - the press secretary for the President of the United States told the assembled reporters that Mr. Trump basically INTENTIONALLY tweeted the mish-mash of letters of #Covfefe.  

Said Sean Spicer, with no apparent attempt at irony or humor: "The president and a small group of people know exactly what he meant.”

But not the millions of people who saw the Tweet!

(It seemed to me that the word at the end of the President's Tweet of "despite the constant negative press ... " was going to be coverage.. but came out "covfefe.")

Meanwhile, #Covfefe is now a meme and punchline, but the President moves to the next big thing ... pulling the U.S. out of the Paris Agreements to fight global warming. Only Syria and Nicaragua of the member nations of the United Nations, are not part of the Paris Agreement.
name: Bill Ritter
title: Donald Trump's strangest tweet ever has become a glorious meme

content:
So what might be the environmental impact of  the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris Accord? 

According to ABC News research gathering --- many groups specializing in this say, "a lot."

Several universities, think tanks and climate groups have taken a stab at projections. The bottom line: greenhouse gas emissions - and subsequently global temperatures - will increase more precipitously than they would have if the U.S. part of the accord, although the exact amount is highly variable and tricky to answer definitively. 
 
The group Climate Interactive projects average temperatures would warm an additional 0.5 degrees Fahrenheit by 2100 if U.S. emissions continue as they are now and every other country fulfills their pledge under the deal. 
 
Another group, Climate Action Tracker, puts the impact of additional warming at 0.18 to 0.36 degrees Fahrenheit -- slightly less because the group finds the U.S. would likely miss its targets under the deal based entirely on Trump's executive orders so far that have rolled back environmental protections. 
 
Meanwhile, the Sierra Club has put out numbers that say 60 percent of the emissions reduction under Paris could be met by local initiatives – states and cities taking matters into their own hands -- but that assumes that the U.S. completely replaces coal with clean energy. 
 
And this from the Associated Press ..
 
The Associated Press consulted with more than two dozen climate scientists and analyzed a special computer model scenario designed to calculate potential effects. Scientists said it would worsen an already bad problem and make it far more difficult to prevent crossing a dangerous global temperature threshold. 

Calculations suggest it could result in emissions of up to 3 billion tons of additional carbon dioxide in the air a year. When it adds up year after year, scientists said that is enough to melt ice sheets faster, raise seas higher and trigger more extreme weather. 

"If we lag, the noose tightens," said Princeton University climate scientist Michael Oppenheimer, co-editor of the peer-reviewed journal Climatic Change.

#BreakingNews. 
 Oscar Lopez Rivera - who was going to be honored at Puerto Rican Day Parade June 11 after spending decades in prison as the leader of a  violent lethal liberation movement group - is now withdrawing as anything but a marcher. No honoree status. 
Will that turn around the exodus of people like Governor Andrew Cuomo, and groups like the NYPD
and New York City Fire Department (FDNY)?  We'll see. 
Here's the statement from NYC  Mayor Bill de Blasio

STATEMENT FROM MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO ON OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA’S INVOLVEMENT IN THE PUERTO RICAN DAY PARADE

“The parade has always been about Puerto Rico and Puerto Ricans, not any one participant. It is a celebration of a culture and community at the center of what makes New York City great. Unfortunately, the parade and the plight of Puerto Rico have been overshadowed by needless controversy. Oscar Lopez Rivera agreeing to step aside from any formal role in the parade is a critical step forward in refocusing our city's attention on the more important issues facing Puerto Rico.

“Puerto Rico and its 3.5 million people, many of whom are family and loved ones of New Yorkers, are in the midst of an economic collapse and health care crisis that threatens their future. Our fellow Americans in Puerto Rico deserve help from Washington and they are not receiving it. This should be our singular focus when it comes to Puerto Rico and our city’s parade.”

content:
I remember being 22 so clearly.. Feels like yesterday.  Then again, feels like forever. A huge and hugely important time of life.  
Tomorrow my second oldest child turns 22.  And for Owen Ritter it is a huge and hugely important time of life. 
But of course, what age isn't? 

When he was born, when the nurse brought him from the birthing bed to the table to be weighed and "inspected,"
the table where I cut his umbilical chord, Owen was crying.  Totally natural of course. But I leaned over and whispered in his ear -- hey Owen.. it's dad.. it's ok.. you don't have to cry. 
And then he stopped. 

Not sure he really heard me, but i have chosen to believe he did.

I will say he's always been pretty good about listening to his pop. He hasn't always agreed - again, totally natural. But he's never ignored me, or us and our conversations. 

One of the tough jobs of raising kids is for parents to allow their children to grow into adults -- and do it without mom or dad obnoxiously holding on to the emotional memories of their kids' childhoods.
I think we've done that Owen. That said .. dang, you were one cute bundle of joy and happiness, humor and smarts, and ever-interesting insights.  

The good news is -- you still are.
Love you Owen Ritter. Your whole family does. 
Happy 22nd Birthday, June 3, 2017. 
Go Forth, Unafraid.
name: Bill Ritter
title: Photos from Bill Ritter's post

content:
Hero London cop who was stabbed confronted terrorists with only his baton. Here's the police account:

Statement from Chief Constable on British Transport Police officer injured at London Bridge
 
London incident

View | Download(JPG - 48 KB)
Following the horrific attacks at London Bridge last night, the British Transport Police officer who was injured is now in a stable condition.

Chief Constable Paul Crowther said: “Having visited the officer in hospital shortly after he was admitted for treatment, I was able to hear his account of what happened last night.

“It became clear that he showed enormous courage in the face of danger, as did many others who were at the scene and rushed to help.

“Although he is seriously unwell, he was able to recount how he faced the attackers armed only with his baton, outside London Bridge station.

“For an officer who only joined us less than two years ago, the bravery he showed was outstanding and makes me extremely proud.

“All of us at BTP wish him a swift recovery, and I know he will be touched by the hundreds of messages of support from across the UK and the world.

“Our thoughts are with all of those who died or were injured, and their loved ones as they try to come to terms with what happened.”

Additional patrols

Members of the public  should expect to see extra police officers patrolling stations in London and the south east following last night’s attacks.

The threat level from international terrorism to the United Kingdom remains at ‘severe’, which means an attack is highly likely.

You may also see some of our armed police officers at stations. Please don’t be alarmed by this, it doesn’t mean there is any specific intelligence relating to the railway, or that there is an increased risk if you are travelling by train or tube. Our officers are there to make sure you feel safe and know that we are there to protect you.

Understandably people are likely to be concerned, so please feel free to talk to any of our officers if you need any help, advice or reassurance.

We ask you to be vigilant and report anything that you see or hear which is suspicious, or just doesn’t feel right.

Suspicious behaviour

If you see something out of place, or unusual, please speak to one of our officers or a member of rail staff.

Look out for the unusual – activity or behaviour that strikes you as not quite right and out of place.

Trust your instincts and report it – we will assess whether the information you have is important or not.

If you see anything suspicious:

·         In an emergency call 999
·         Call the anti-terrorist hotline on 0800 789 321
·         Call British Transport Police on 0800 40 50 40 or text us on 61016
Find out how to ACT to counter terrorism.
name: Bill Ritter

I've just discovered the secret to solving the health care crisis. Pet insurance!
Never before - never ever ever never - have I had more reliable coverage. Pay the premium. Meet the deductible. Go to the vet and -- bam! -- 2 weeks later there's a check in the mail for 90% of the vet bill. 
My personal health care insurer? Same day as the check from the vet visit 2 weeks ago I got explanation of benefits (zero !) from a giant insurance company - for service by a doctor from .. wait for it ... January, 2017!
So.. the secret...  everyone move to pet insurance!  O'canine care!

content:
The 7 quick takeaways from James Comey's prepared Senate testimony - according to New York Magazine.

1) Comey corroborates virtually everything that’s been reported about his relationship with Trump.
2) The president was very clear that he did not want an FBI director who was loyal to the country, but rather, to him, personally.
3) The FBI director does not believe that Trump directly asked him to drop the investigation into links between Russia and his campaign.
4) Trump was telling the truth – Comey really did assure him, three times, that he was not personally under FBI investigation.
5) Trump really wanted James Comey to know that there is no “pee tape.”
6) Comey knew, early on, that his relationship with Trump would be fundamentally different than the one he had with Barack Obama.
7) The president has either seen too many mafia movies…or worked with too many mobsters.
name: Bill Ritter
title: 7 Quick Takeaways From James Comey’s Testimony About President Trump

content:
#BreakingNews President Donald J. Trump says he's willing to testify under oath to refute the testimony of the FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation director he fired, James Comey. 

In an exchange with ABC News reporter Jonathan Karl, Mr. Trump denied he asked Comey to drop the investigation of General Flynn and also denied he asked Comey for a pledge of loyalty. 

As for whether tapes exist in the oval office ...the President  he'd let everyone know "over a short period of time" -  but when Karl pressed him on their existence,  Mr. Trump said that we'd "be very disappointed when you hear the answer." 

here's the verbate of some of the exchange: 

KARL>> Always fair. Mr. President, I want to get back to James Comey's testimony. You suggested he didn't tell the truth in everything he said. He did say under oath that you told him to let the Flynn -- you said you hoped the Flynn investigation -- 
 
TRUMP>> I didn't say that. 
 
KARL>> So he lied about that? 
 
TRUMP>> Well, I didn't say that. I will tell you, I didn't say that. 
 
KARL>> And did he ask you to pledge -- 
TRUMP>> And there would be nothing wrong if I did say it according to everybody that I read today but I did not say that.
name: Bill Ritter

content:
Two pictures of the indomitable Dr. Ruth Westheimer, who turned 89 last Sunday. At the 100th gala of the  YM & YWHA of Washington Heights & Inwood.. 
I first met Dr. Ruth 21 years ago when I was doing a "Sex Over 50" series for Good Morning America.  Ruth looks the same. Me? I had no gray hair back then!
She was fantabulous on the series, with some very practical and honest advice. 
One of the stories in the series was also one of the most uncomfortable moments for me on air. I was doing a story about ... lubricants ("Sex Over 50" was after all the title of the series).. and I remember on my live tag on the set with my great mentor Charles Gibson... I repeated the expert's advice to use water-based lubricants, not oil-based. 
And Charlie - who always has something smart to say - was just speechless, looking at me with what might have been a bubble over his head, that could have said: What did you just say on my show????   I've never seen Charlie speechless... until then. 
Thanks Dr. Ruth!  You always tell it like it is.. even  if it made Charlie Gibson speechless!
name: Bill Ritter
title: Photos from Bill Ritter's post

more controversy tonight involving the question of art and political statements.  The 2017 production of "Julius Caesar" at the Central Park summer venue for Shakespeare In The Park has sparked huge controversy because it seems to depict the murder of the President. Both Delta Airlines and the Bank of America have withdrawn their funding of the play - a huge deal because the public is allowed in for free because the production cost is funded by corporations. 
Corporate sponsors withdrawing is now itself controversial. There's this case - and last weekend's example of the Puerto Rican Day Parade, where some sponsors withdrew because of the honorees was viewed as a terrorist because he was aligned to a now-dormant violent nationalistic group.  
what think? we're on the story on this, opening night of the production in the park.

most of us will never forget the attacks of sept. 11.  i will also never forget the work that day of  each of my colleagues at ABC7NY ... including a young Michelle Charlesworth who reasoned  that she and many others of her generation would remember this as a day that they lost their innocence. 
With the buildings behind her getting attacked by hijacked airplanes, and on fire, Michelle was on the West Side Highway as thousands of people walked north - away from the carnage. 
Today, Michelle and her photographer that day, Fred Mason, were covering the relocation of the 9/11 Tribute Museum. 
All these memories - of stories big and small - is why we at Eyewitness News think of ourselves as family. 
You are part of my family, Michelle.  And I'm better for it.
name: Bill Ritter
title: Michelle Charlesworth

content:
Stunning testimony from Atty. Gen. Sessions with Sen King just now about Russian interference in the election - and Mr. Sessions not ever reading the intelligence documents and findings from 17 agencies - this was before he recused himself.

KING>> Do you believe the Russians interfered with the 2016 elections? 
 
SESSIONS>> It appears so. The intelligence community seems to be united in that, but I have to tell you, senator king, I know nothing but what I've read in the paper. I've never received any details, briefing on how hacking occurred or how information was alleged to have influenced the campaigns. 
 
KING>> Between the election, there was a memorandum from the intelligence community on October 9th, that detailed what the Russians were doing after the election, before the inauguration. You never sought any information about this rather dramatic attack on our country? 
 
SESSIONS>> No. 
 
>> You never asked for a briefing or attended a briefing or ruled are the intelligence reports? 
 
>> You might have been very critical if I as an active part of the campaign was seeking intelligence related to something that might be relevant to the campaign. I'm not sure -- 
 
KING>> I'm not talking about the campaign. I'm talking about what the Russians did. You received no briefing on the Russian active measures in connection with the 2016 election. 
 
SESSIONS>> No, I don't believe I ever did. 
 .

content:
attention anyone who loves the nation's incredible national parks.  Is the President Donald J. Trump administration seeking to privatize public campsites?

From an ABC News staffer covering this story: 

Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke is suggesting that the department is looking at handing over management of public campsites to private companies, in remarks to the RV industry association last week. Zinke, similar to other administration officials, has talked about the need for better partnerships with industry.

The full quote is below, from the event provided by RVBusiness, a trade magazine for the RV industry that covered the event.

"I don't want, as a secretary, I don't want to be in the business of running campgrounds. A, is my folks will never be as good as you are on it. So the President has said five star experience. Make sure the experience when you go through our nations parks is five star. Make sure we're wearing the right uniform. Make sire the bathrooms are clean, and make sure we find the best talent to deliver services. We should be your interpretive guys. We should be the managers of the forest, those type of things, but when it comes to running our campgrounds, we should get the very best, and that's you."

Some reactions to these comments have already expressed concern that letting private companies into public campgrounds could drive up prices, like one report in the Santa Fe New Mexican. Zinke also mentioned other chances for public-private partnerships like upgrading transportation within the parks, integrating cell phones more with apps that can be used to interact with different parts of the parks.

Zinke has also suggested that opening federal lands up to oil and gas drilling could help bringing in money for the department but a report released last week by the National Parks Conservation Association says that drilling could threaten at least seven parks, including Carlsbad Caverns and Zion national parks, by disrupting wildlife or through light and sound pollution.

content:
Update on gun violence deaths in the U.S. this past week - june 7-14. 
at least 286 people have been killed by gun violence, 559 injured, according to the Gun Violence Archive, a non-profit that collects daily data from media and law enforcement sources. 
The numbers EXCLUDE suicides (except possible murder-suicide), which are difficult to track in real-time.
 
In addition, when GVA pulled its data for “one year after Pulse” they found that averages are moving up.  The number of people killed and injured is up in this past 12 months over GVA’s four year averages, according to the group.
 
For the first three years that GVA tracked data, there was an average of 36 deaths per day. Last year that number went up to 41 and it is on pace to be higher this year.

content:
45 years ago. Watergate.  A break in at Democratic National Committee Headquarters at the Watergate Hotel on June 17, 1972, by some burglars with connections to people from the Nixon re-election campaign. 
A break in, followed by a cover up, and a scandal that revealed the crookedness of the system that financed political campaigns, the crookedness of the men (and they were all men) who rode the coattails of power in The White House​, and, ultimately, the crookedness of the President himself, Richard Nixon. 
A 2-hour TV documentary from ABC News. Friday night, 9 p.m., followed by ABC7NY news at 11. 

I became a reporter because of Watergate. 
I watched the hearings, read the papers, and became committed to a job that demands finding truth and peddling facts. 

When Richard Nixon ran for re-election in 1972 - Watergate happened right before the political conventions of the summer of '72 - his slogan was: "Now More Than Ever."

I feel that way now about journalism. 
Now, more than ever.
name: Bill Ritter
title: ABC 20/20

content:
feel so terrible for the family of #OttoWarmbier, the student who was jailed in North Korea .. and who this afternoon has died. he was jailed for 17 months for allegedly trying to steal a poster from a hotel room. the conventional wisdom is he was beaten. 
At least his family was able to see him - albeit in a coma. the whole thing is just so sad. 

CINCINNATI, OHIO – 6/19/17 – The following statement is issued at the request of Fred & Cindy Warmbier and family:

 
It is our sad duty to report that our son, Otto Warmbier, has completed his journey home.  Surrounded by his loving family, Otto died today at 2:20pm.
It would be easy at a moment like this to focus on all that we lost – future time that won’t be spent with a warm, engaging, brilliant young man whose curiosity and enthusiasm for life knew no bounds. But we choose to focus on the time we were given to be with this remarkable person.  You can tell from the outpouring of emotion from the communities that he touched – Wyoming, Ohio and the University of Virginia to name just two – that the love for Otto went well beyond his immediate family.
We would like to thank the wonderful professionals at the University of Cincinnati Medical Center who did everything they could for Otto. Unfortunately, the awful torturous mistreatment our son received at the hands of the North Koreans ensured that no other outcome was possible beyond the sad one we experienced today.
When Otto returned to Cincinnati late on June 13th he was unable to speak, unable to see and unable to react to verbal commands. He looked very uncomfortable – almost anguished.  Although we would never hear his voice again, within a day the countenance of his face changed – he was at peace.  He was home and we believe he could sense that.  
We thank everyone around the world who has kept him and our family in their thoughts and prayers.   We are at peace and at home too.
-       Fred & Cindy Warmbier and Family

content:
for anyone who wonders whether being in nature doesn't make a difference, and change a youngster, and leave them with a lifetime of memories and lessons.... my oldest daughter Mia Ritter... who became a canoe expert... who went back to her camp to counsel others... who led wilderness treks.. and who now is entrenched in college admissions as an administrator and soon will go after her masters to counsel young students.... summer time in the wilderness matters.. and makes a difference- writes about her summer camp, Camp Arcadia (Casco, ME). 
if you can - help fund a young camper who can't afford it. 

Below is Mia's memory of camp, as another summer of camp is about to begin.
(And she's a good writer! shocker!)

Here's what Mia wrote: 
I feel so nostalgic for this view. For the people I've met and loved and cared so deeply about. To everyone at camp today, cherish that first supper where every camper is seeing their long lost sister for the first time, hugging their old counselor while almost dropping their tray of spaghetti, and running down the hill to see the lake (and get their bed). Smell the breeze and the dirt and the pines. Be present. Love every moment, even when you want to cry after you slam your canoe into the dock for the 19th time in 54 minutes. Always be true blue and hold these moments as close as you can.

content:
So i have a thick skin - i think anyone in the public eye has to. 
But this vitriolic post is a first. Of all the things I've been called - and some of the descriptions may be  accurate - I've never been called stupid. Until now. 
If I weren't accustomed to posting regularly and getting feedback - if I were sensitive about all this - might this not be a case of cyber-bullying?  Just spreading hate, hiding behind a fake name, rather than offering constructive criticism? 
There's a reason my hashtag mantra this year is #NoMeanIn17. 
Lot's of constructive criticism to be made - and received. 
Let's be kind to each other.

content:
RIP GABE PRESSMAN.

By the time I arrived in NYC, Gabe was already a legend -
 68 years old and still going strong with the energy of a 40 year old, and the wisdom of the local TV news dean he was. 
When I found out he had started in newspapers - as many journalists in his generation did - -I felt an immediate bond because, only 6 years  before, I too had been a newspaper reporter for many years.  So I got him. And it was a joy to watch him work. 

Gabe was 93 when he died in his sleep  last night. He was still active, still crusading for the First Amendment, for reporting, for finding the truth and facts. 

He was still involved in the New York Press club, and his speech there on June 5 burnished his already strong commitment to mentoring reporters, and to follow the basic tenets of journalism. We can't give up. We have to keep fighting for our rights as journalists." 

There's a reason we look up to those who went before us.  There's a reason we looked up to Gabe. And always will. 

We at ABC7NY mourn his death, and are thinking of Gabe's family at home, and his family at the newsroom down the street at NBC New York
 
You lived a good life Gabe, and made a big impact on this big city.

title: Timeline Photos

content:
#BreakingNews.   Supreme Court allows President Donald J. Trump travel ban with one "if" 

WASHINGTON (AP) - The Supreme Court is letting a limited version of the Trump administration ban on travel from six mostly Muslim countries to take effect, a victory for President Donald Trump in the biggest legal controversy of his young presidency.
         
The court said Monday the ban on visitors from Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen could be enforced as long as they lack a "credible claim of a bona fide relationship with a person or entity in the United States." The justices will hear arguments in the case in October.
         
Trump said last week that the ban would take effect 72 hours after being cleared by courts.
         
The Trump administration said the 90-day ban was needed to allow an internal review of the screening procedures for visa applicants from those countries. That review should be complete before Oct. 2, the first day the justices could hear arguments in their new term.
         
A 120-ban on refugees also is being allowed to take effect on a limited basis.
         
Three of the court's conservative justices said they would have let the complete bans take effect.
         
Justice Clarence Thomas, joined by Justices Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch, said the government has shown it is likely to succeed on the merits of the case, and that it will suffer irreparable harm with any interference. Thomas said the government's interest in preserving national security outweighs any hardship to people denied entry into the country.
         
Two federal appeals courts had blocked the travel policy, which Trump announced a week after he took office in January and revised in March after setbacks in court.
         
The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, said the ban was "rooted in religious animus" toward Muslims and pointed to Trump's campaign promise to impose a ban on Muslims entering the country as well as tweets and remarks he has made since becoming president.
         
The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the travel policy does not comply with federal immigration law, including a prohibition on nationality-based discrimination. That court also put a hold on separate aspects of the policy that would keep all refugees out of the United States for 120 days and cut by more than half, from 110,000 to 50,000, the cap on refugees in the current government spending year that ends September 30.
         
Trump's first executive order on travel applied to travelers from the six countries as well as Iraq, and took effect immediately, causing chaos and panic at airports over the last weekend in January as the Homeland Security Department scrambled to figure out who the order covered and how it was to be implemented.
         
A federal judge blocked it eight days later, an order that was upheld by a 9th circuit panel. Rather than pursue an appeal, the administration said it would revise the policy.
         
In March, Trump issued the narrower order.
name: Bill Ritter

QUICK HIGHLIGHTS:
--The Senate bill would increase the number of people who are uninsured by 22 million in 2026 relative to the number under current law, slightly fewer than the increase in the number of uninsured estimated for the House-passed legislation. 
--By 2026, an estimated 49 million people would be uninsured, compared with 28 million who would lack insurance that year under current law.
--Would reduce the cumulative federal deficit over the 2017-2026 period by $321 billion. That amount is $202 billion more than the estimated net savings for the version of H.R. 1628 that was passed by the House of Representatives.

content:
since the "R" word made news on my social media pages tonight... I thought I'd share a very brief history with my quite personal story about the R word. 

I had a brother who was born severely disabled .. a bad heart and with Down Syndrome ... back in 1957. Alex was his name .. named after my dad's father Albert, who had died a couple of years earlier. 
Alex lived less than 2 weeks. 

When my parents had emerged from their acute sorrow, they decided that they wanted to get involved with an organization to improve the lives of people born with Down Syndrome.  
It was called the National Association for R******* Children. 
They proudly joined it. The organization proudly hoisted its banner with that name on it. 
Times would later change.  And the Association .. changed its name, after the R word became to be seen as something derogatory rather than perceived as innocently descriptive (and one could argue that it was  never that.)

I was always proud of my parents' volunteer work with the Association. But I remember being uncomfortable and offended when a kid at school was use the R word as a slam on someone, say, at the ballfield.  
Hey, I'd say, I had a brother was "R."  And they would rightly quiet down .. perhaps not ever understanding until that moment that it might be offensive and inappropriate and cruel. 

Heck, had Alex not been born maybe I wouldn't have understood it either. 

Since then, and especially since my parents died, I have tried to give up myself to organizations that serve people with disabilities. I have emceeded since 2000 the annual Central Park Challenge sponsored by YAI, which promotes a level playing field for the people with disabilities that it serves so well. 

So that's why I responded to the "reporters are R..." by the school Tweet that we now know was hacked. 
For me, it's not just being politically correct. 
It's personal.
name: Bill Ritter
title: The Arc | Name Change History

Office of the Press Secretary
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
June 26, 2017
 
Statement from the Press Secretary
 
The United States has identified potential preparations for another chemical weapons attack by the Assad regime that would likely result in the mass murder of civilians, including innocent children.  The activities are similar to preparations the regime made before its April 4, 2017 chemical weapons attack.
 
As we have previously stated, the United States is in Syria to eliminate the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.  If, however, Mr. Assad conducts another mass murder attack using chemical weapons, he and his military will pay a heavy price.

content:
more than a million rent-regulated apartments in NYC.

 designed to help keep "middle class" people in the city. to qualify for rent-regulated apartment living - you can't make more than $175,000 a year.  

in most cities, that makes you upper crust.  in nyc - you qualify for rent-regulated apartments. 
have your costs gone up more than 1% in the past year? of course they have. which makes it very difficult for landlords of rent-regulated apartment.

on the other hand, it's difficult for many rent-regulated tenants (most do NOT make $175,000 a year!).. because a 1% raise in rent is a lot if you're not working. 

I'M NOT TAKING A SIDE HERE..   
i'm just saying that this annual debate and battle between tenants and landlords has no real winners.. and two sides that, arguably, lose. 
it seems from my perch a very difficult stew of private sector and regulated housing. 
is it the best we can come up with? judging by experience, one might conclude, yes. 

tonight the new vote:
name: Bill Ritter
title: NYC Rent Guidelines Board votes to increase rent for 1, 2-year leases

content:
latest Quinnipiac University poll re: health care proposal by Republicans. 
stunning numbers of disapproval. 

Healthcare bill approval among all Americans:
16% approve
58% disapprove
26% don’t know, no answer

Healthcare bill approval among Republicans:
37% approve
23% disapprove
40% don’t know/no answer

When asked if voting for the bill would make you less likely/more likely to support a congressional candidate:
17% more likely (35% of GOP voters said more likely)
46% less likely (48% of independents said less likely, 9% of GOP voters)
33% say it won’t matter

Some other interesting findings: 
71% oppose cutting Medicaid
61% oppose defunding Planned Parenthood
46%, a plurality, say a vote for repealing Obamacare will make them less likely to vote for their senator or representative

One last (very interesting) number, on gun control:
94% of all respondents favor requiring background checks for all gun buyers.

93% of Republicans favor, 98% of Democrats favor and 95% of Independents favor.

the derailment of a Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) subway had nothing to do with the aging system. not this time. in fact, an argument can be made that the derailment happened in the middle of an upgrade to the aging system. 
but it was boneheaded stupidity ... workers didn't secure the replacement rails they were working on... and they came loose.. and they hit the train..and then it derailed. 
2 people now suspended.

content:
The Supreme Court ruling about the Travel Ban gave a pass to anyone trying to get into the U.S. from the 6 Muslim-majority nations -- who had a direct tie to someone here. A family member. A friend. A job. Some connection. 
But tonight the President Donald J. Trump Administration putting out new criteria about what the meaning of connection is. 

The Associated Press reporting: 

"The new guidelines sent to U.S. embassies and consulates on Wednesday say that applicants from the six countries must prove a relationship with a parent, spouse, child, adult son or daughter, son-in-law, daughter-in-law or sibling in the U.S.
 
This is according to a State Department cable obtained by the Associated Press.
 
Grandparents, grandchildren, aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins, brothers-laws and sisters-in-law, fiancees or other extended family members are not considered to be close relationships."

Will the appeals now begin?
name: Bill Ritter
